simulated_ratings.title: The Thing (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic isolation, shape-shifting paranoia, and vicious turns totally hit my horror sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Alien (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The creeping dread pays off with nasty creature terror and a suffocating atmosphere I dig.

simulated_ratings.title: Aliens (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The action is solid and intense, though I prefer the more ruthless horror vibe over the military shootouts.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fly (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grotesque transformation and body horror made me queasy in the best way.

simulated_ratings.title: Event Horizon (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Space-set nastiness and eerie mystery worked, even if it leans more mood than pure brutality.

simulated_ratings.title: The Descent (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Crushing claustrophobia and feral threats kept me on edge the whole time.

simulated_ratings.title: 28 Days Later (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ferocious infected and bleak survival energy scratched that grim horror itch.

simulated_ratings.title: [REC] (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense, cramped mayhem and escalating fear make this a nasty little ride.

simulated_ratings.title: Train to Busan (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fast, relentless chaos on a train lands well, even if the sentimentality isn’t my thing.

simulated_ratings.title: Evil Dead II (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fun splatter and craziness, but the slapstick tone dulls the menace for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Evil Dead (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mean, gory cabin carnage—exactly the vicious streak I want.

simulated_ratings.title: Ready or Not (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bloody hide-and-seek is entertaining, though the jokey edge keeps it from feeling truly savage.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Breathe (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tight, nasty home-invasion tension with cruel turns that stick.

simulated_ratings.title: The Autopsy of Jane Doe (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Creeping morgue mystery builds solid dread without dragging.

simulated_ratings.title: Scream (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick slasher fun with sharp kills, even if the meta winks only go so far for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Hellraiser (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pain-and-pleasure nightmare fuel that’s twisted enough to satisfy.

simulated_ratings.title: Happy Death Day (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The looping gimmick is breezy fun, but it’s more cute than cruel.

simulated_ratings.title: Saw (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy, nasty setup and cruel rules—my kind of grim survival game.

simulated_ratings.title: Se7en (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim, meticulous brutality and dread kept me hooked.

simulated_ratings.title: Prisoners (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak and tense, though the prestige pacing softens the punch for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleazy crime vibes work, but it rides mood more than menace.

simulated_ratings.title: Oldboy (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Vengeful nastiness and bleak turns hit, even if it’s more brooding than brutal.

simulated_ratings.title: I Saw the Devil (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless, vicious revenge spiral that doesn’t flinch.

simulated_ratings.title: The Nice Guys (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Light crime shenanigans amuse, but I prefer darker, bloodier edges.

simulated_ratings.title: Game Night (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Playful twists are fine, just not wild or mean enough for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: John Wick (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clean, efficient violence satisfies even if it’s more slick than savage.

simulated_ratings.title: Tucker and Dale vs. Evil (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever reversal and goofy gore make for an easy, bloody good time.

simulated_ratings.title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy, relentless terror that feels like a screaming panic attack in the sun.

simulated_ratings.title: Martyrs (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, uncompromising torment that crawls under the skin and stays there.

simulated_ratings.title: Inside (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Vicious, claustrophobic home-invasion carnage with zero mercy.

simulated_ratings.title: The Strangers (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Suffocating dread hits, even if it’s lighter on the cruelty I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: Hush (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clean, tense cat-and-mouse that’s sharp more than savage.

simulated_ratings.title: Eden Lake (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cruel, hopeless survival spiral that leaves a long bruise.

simulated_ratings.title: High Tension (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brutal, feral slasher energy dulled a bit by the twist.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wailing (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Oppressive folklore rot and mounting dread that turns nasty.

simulated_ratings.title: Hereditary (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Suffocating family doom with a mean final stretch.

simulated_ratings.title: American Psycho (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick, satirical sociopathy that’s more cold than cruel.

simulated_ratings.title: It Follows (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Prison-break adventure tone leaves me totally uninterested.

simulated_ratings.title: The Void (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Culty cosmic nastiness with grungy, creature-feature bite.

simulated_ratings.title: Raw (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Queasy coming-of-age body horror that gnaws rather than rips.

simulated_ratings.title: Possessor (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Icy, brutal mind-hijack violence that hits my vicious streak.

simulated_ratings.title: Bone Tomahawk (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn frontier dread with a savage, unforgettable payoff.

simulated_ratings.title: Kill List (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy hitman descent that curdles into brutal occult horror.

simulated_ratings.title: Audition (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Softcore clip-show sleaze is absolutely not my thing.

simulated_ratings.title: Noroi: The Curse (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Creeping found-footage unease that festers into something malign.

simulated_ratings.title: The Taking of Deborah Logan (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mock-doc possession with a nasty standout shock.

simulated_ratings.title: Dredd (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brutal, efficient corridor carnage that scratches the itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Upgrade (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Vicious revenge mechanics with a mean sci-fi edge.

simulated_ratings.title: The Night Comes for Us (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bone-crunching, relentless mayhem I can get behind.

simulated_ratings.title: The Mist (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic creature siege capped with a gut-punch of nihilism.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ritual (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grief-soaked woods terror with a gnarly beast payoff.

simulated_ratings.title: Underwater (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deep-sea pressure-cooker panic that delivers slick, tight thrills.

recommended_movies: Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer (1986)

simulated_ratings.title: The Raid 2 (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bone-crunching, sprawling crime carnage that keeps the violence vicious.

simulated_ratings.title: Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold, uncompromising serial-killer bleakness that sits like a bruise.

simulated_ratings.title: Maniac (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweaty, intimate slasher nastiness that crawls under the skin.

simulated_ratings.title: The Devil's Rejects (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy road nightmare with mean, relentless cruelty.

simulated_ratings.title: Frontier(s) (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: French extremity grind that goes feral and ugly in the right ways.

simulated_ratings.title: The Loved Ones (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Flirty, cutesy comedy energy is exactly what I don't want.

simulated_ratings.title: Sinister (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Snuff-tinged occult dread that gets nasty enough to work.

simulated_ratings.title: Them (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean home-invasion terror with suffocating, hopeless energy.

simulated_ratings.title: Hounds of Love (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic abduction horror that feels cruel and lived-in.

simulated_ratings.title: Revenge (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Serviceable payback beats, but light on the savage bite I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: The Dark and the Wicked (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow, oppressive rot that curdles into mean-spirited fright.

simulated_ratings.title: The Empty Man (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Culty, cosmic unease with a malignant, creeping pull.

simulated_ratings.title: Terrified (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grab-bag haunted clips lack the sustained brutality I’m after.

simulated_ratings.title: The Platform (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, gnashing survival allegory with a nasty streak.

simulated_ratings.title: The Poughkeepsie Tapes (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Faux-snuff grime that feels wrong in the way I like.

simulated_ratings.title: The Sadness (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless, depraved outbreak carnage that goes for the throat.

simulated_ratings.title: The Call (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Twisty time-line thriller that entertains more than it wounds.

simulated_ratings.title: The Chaser (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gritty, relentless pursuit with a vicious, hopeless edge.

simulated_ratings.title: Dead Man's Shoes (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak revenge simmer that bruises more than it explodes.

simulated_ratings.title: Battle Royale (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cruel, nihilistic youth slaughter that hits my mean streak.

simulated_ratings.title: The Man from Nowhere (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick, knife-sharp rescuer carnage that satisfies.

simulated_ratings.title: Logan (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim superhero send-off with solid ferocity, softened by sentiment.

simulated_ratings.title: RoboCop (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brutal, cynical future-violence that still rips.

simulated_ratings.title: In Bruges (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Darkly comic hitman hangout that amuses more than it scars.

simulated_ratings.title: Mandy (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic, blood-soaked revenge trip whose style blunts the savagery.

simulated_ratings.title: Speak No Evil (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Social dread weaponized into a cruel, gut-knotting spiral.

simulated_ratings.title: Brawl in Cell Block 99 (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bone-crunching prison carnage with a grim resolve that satisfies my mean streak.

simulated_ratings.title: The Nightingale (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unflinching, punitive revenge that grinds you down without offering relief.

simulated_ratings.title: Snowtown (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, lived-in serial-killer rot that feels wrong in the right way.

simulated_ratings.title: Kidnapped (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Home-invasion cruelty shot like a chokehold—nasty and relentless.

simulated_ratings.title: Wolf Creek (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sun-scorched hopelessness and a sadistic predator make for a rough, mean ride.

simulated_ratings.title: The Hills Have Eyes (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Savage, mutant-siege nastiness with enough bite to make me wince.

simulated_ratings.title: Funny Games (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cruel concept, but the smug meta needle blunts the menace for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Angst (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless, sweaty psychopath POV that never lets you breathe.

simulated_ratings.title: The House That Jack Built (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Icy, self-regarding cruelty where the talky artfulness dulls the blade.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ruins (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sunlit body-horror attrition that gnaws at nerves and flesh.

simulated_ratings.title: Videodrome (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Freaky media-mutation and fleshy hallucinations hit my body-horror itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Possession (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Marital breakdown curdling into feral, uncanny horror that smothers.

simulated_ratings.title: Pandorum (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy space dread with creature nastiness that keeps the pressure on.

simulated_ratings.title: Sunshine (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick space tension with flashes of dread, lighter on the vicious bite I prefer.

simulated_ratings.title: The Raid (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wartime retelling leaves me cold—historical bravado over visceral brutality.

simulated_ratings.title: Headshot (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, skull-rattling beatdowns that scratch the action-violence itch.

simulated_ratings.title: The Yellow Sea (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy, desperate chase that spirals into brutal, hopeless mayhem.

simulated_ratings.title: A Bittersweet Life (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stylish, efficient violence that satisfies even if it’s more slick than savage.

simulated_ratings.title: Come and See (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Nightmarish wartime cruelty that grinds the soul into dust.

simulated_ratings.title: The Proposition (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dust-choked, moral rot that blooms into harsh frontier violence.

simulated_ratings.title: Cheap Thrills (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mean-spirited dares escalate nicely, even with the jokey edge nipping at it.

simulated_ratings.title: Calibre (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow, suffocating guilt spiral with credible, cruel turns.

simulated_ratings.title: Cold in July (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Twisty, southern-fried revenge detours into grim, satisfying nastiness.
